sn35.130:1.1: At one time Venerable Mahākaccāna was staying in the land of the Avantis near Kuraraghara on Steep Mountain.
sn35.130:1.2: Then the householder Hāliddikāni went up to Venerable Mahākaccāna … and asked him,
sn35.130:1.3: “Sir, this was said by the Buddha:
sn35.130:1.4: ‘Diversity of elements gives rise to diversity of contacts, and diversity of contacts gives rise to diversity of feelings.’
sn35.130:1.5: How does diversity of elements give rise to diversity of contacts, and diversity of contacts gives rise to diversity of feelings?”
sn35.130:1.6: “Householder, it’s when a mendicant sees a sight and understands it to be agreeable.
sn35.130:1.7: There is eye consciousness; and pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant.
sn35.130:1.8: Then they see a sight and understand it to be disagreeable.
sn35.130:1.9: There is eye consciousness; and painful feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful.
sn35.130:1.10: Then they see a sight and understand it to be a basis for equanimity.
sn35.130:1.11: There is eye consciousness; and neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral.
sn35.130:2.1: Furthermore, a mendicant hears a sound with the ear …
sn35.130:2.2: smells an odor with the nose …
sn35.130:2.3: tastes a flavor with the tongue …
sn35.130:2.4: feels a touch with the body …
sn35.130:2.5: knows a thought with the mind and understands it to be agreeable.
sn35.130:2.6: There is mind consciousness; and pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant.
sn35.130:2.7: Then they know a thought and understand it to be disagreeable.
sn35.130:2.8: There is mind consciousness; and painful feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful.
sn35.130:2.9: Then they know a thought and understand it to be a basis for equanimity.
sn35.130:2.10: Neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral.
sn35.130:2.11: That’s how diversity of elements gives rise to diversity of contacts, and diversity of contacts gives rise to diversity of feelings.”
